awd_titl_txt: CAREER: SusChEM: Electrocatalytic Valorization of Biomass Intermediates via 1st-Row Transition Metal Electrocatalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
Biomass, obtained from waste agricultural materials or efficiently - grown plants, has the potential to be a significant, renewable source of clean energy and chemical feedstocks if appropriate methods of chemical conversion can be developed.  Dr. Yujie Sun of Utah State University is supported by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division to pursue research into the investigation of biomass conversion using a novel electrocatalytic process.  Electrocatalysis uses electrons provided by an electric current to drive chemical reactions in the controlled and efficient process of catalysis, a chemical pathway that increases the speed and efficiency of the chemical converstion. Dr. Sun's research elucidates the chemical reaction pathways, or mechanistic steps, of the electrocatalytic oxidation of biomass molecules and establishes the relationship between the catalyst composition and its catalytic activity for 1st-row transition metal-based electrocatalysts.  For good conductivity and efficient catalytic activity, the transition metals are fabricated as very thin films known as two-dimensional ultrathin "nanosheets". Broader impacts of the research result from the development of an efficient biomass conversion process to produce fuels and other chemicals from renewable biomoass resources. Dr. Sun also creates broader impact opportunities in his work with students in education and outreach activities.  He is actively engaged in outreach programs focusing on attracting and mentoring students from groups that are under - represented in the STEM fields, such as Native American undergraduates and economically disadvantaged high school students, as well as creating cutting - edge research-based opportunities in experimental courses for undergraduate students at Utah State University.  

Even though biomass valorization has been recognized as an attractive strategy in producing nonfossil- based chemical products, the conventional upgrading approaches often require harsh conditions, toxic regents, and/or expensive catalysts. With the support of this CAREER award from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Yujie Sun of Utah State University is developing an alternative electrocatalytic approach for biomass upgrading utilizing 1st row transition metal-based electrocatalysts. In particular, this project elucidates the mechanistic steps of the electrocatalytic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF, one of the top biomass-derived platform chemicals) under ambient conditions and establishes a composition - activity relationship of 1st-row transition metal oxides (TMOs) for HMF valorization. Using this information, ultrathin two-dimensional (2D) TMOs of the most promising compositions are prepared and interrogated to obtain their intrinsic electrocatalytic activities for HMF oxidation.  The ultrathin electocatalyst thickness is designed to circumvent electric resistivity problems. The experimental activities are supported with density functional theory (DFT) calculations, conducted in parallel with the experiments, and are used to aid the interpretation of measured activity trends and other variables in the composition-activity relationship. Broader impacts of the research result from the development of an efficient biomass conversion process to produce fuels and other chemicals from renewable biomoass resources. Dr. Sun also creates opportunities for broader impacts in student training and mentorship in his education and outreach activities.  He is actively engaged in outreach programs that are focused on students from groups under - represented in the STEM fields, such as Native American undergraduates and economically disadvantaged high school students, as well as creating cutting - edge research-based opportunities in experimental courses for undergraduate students in Utah.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The increasing global energy demand and critical concerns of climate change resulting from fossil fuel utilization have motivated considerable efforts in developing sustainable and clean energy storage and conversion technologies. Electrocatalytic water splitting with renewable energy input to produce clean H2 has been considered as a promising approach for future energy needs. Despite the tremendous efforts devoted in water splitting, the wide deployment of water splitting electrolyzers for H2 generation is still impeded by the low energy conversion efficiency and lack of competent and inexpensive catalysts, mainly due to the anodic half reaction of O2 evolution (OER). The overall H2 evolution reaction (HER) rate is often limited by the OER rate because of the more sluggish kinetics of the latter. Therefore, typically much higher overpotential is required for OER to match the rate of HER, thus lowering the overall energy conversion efficiency. More importantly, the product of OER, O2, is not a chemical of high value. Therefore, it is economically attractive to explore thermodynamically more favorable oxidation reactions which can not only replace OER but also generate value-added products at the anode.

This NSF CAREER award has funded the study of the Sun group in developing and understanding various electrocatalytic systems for the upgrading of biomass-derived furanics, such as furfural and HMF, to value-added products. These oxidative biomass valorization reactions can be integrated with cathodic water reduction to produce H2. Hence, the overall voltage input will be substantially reduced compared to overall water splitting and simultaneously two types of valuable products are generated at both anode and cathode of an electrolyzer. Over the period of this award, the PI?s group has reported a variety of 1st-row transition metal-based electrocatalytic systems for the efficient oxidation of biomass-derived platform molecules to valuable products, such as 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), a green replacement of terephthalic acid. Systematic studies of alcohol oxidation on nickel-based electrocatalysts under alkaline conditions demonstrated that onset potential of their electrocatalytic oxidation is mainly dictated by the formation potential of high-valent nickel species, rather than the intrinsic thermodynamic oxidation potential of each alcohol substrate.

In addition to the production of biopolymer precursors like FDCA, this award also supported the PI?s group to explore the electrocatalytic synthesis of heterocycles from biomass-derived furanics. Furthermore, different from conventional metal oxides/hydroxides/oxyhydroxides, hybrid electrocatalysts with molecular active sites were also developed and investigated. For instance, taking advantage of photo-induced polymerization of a bipyridyl ligand, we demonstrated the facile preparation of a heterogenized nickel electrocatalyst, which effectively drives the Achmatowicz reaction electrochemically (see the attached figure). The Achmatowicz reaction is able to convert furfuryl alcohol into substituted dihydropyranone acetals, which find applications in the synthesis of natural products and pharmaceuticals. Detailed experimental and computational studies revealed that the unsaturated coordination sphere of nickel sites plays an important role at low applied potential, not only allowing the intimate interaction between the nickel center and furfuryl alcohol but also enabling the transfer of hydroxide from nickel to the bound furfuryl alcohol. Other integrated electrocatalytic systems have also been developed by the PI?s group for the selective conversion of biomass-derived a-hydroxyl acids to valuable a-amino acids, including natural amino acids like glycine, alanine, and leucine.

Overall, the fundamental composition-structure-activity relationships of a number of 1st-row transition metal-based electrocatalytic systems for biomass valorization were discovered and reported under the support of this NSF CAREER award. It is anticipated that the knowledge gained from this award can be readily applied to many other electrocatalytic organic transformations, which will facilitate the paradigm shift from our current fossil fuel-dominated economy to a renewable energy/carbon-based economy. Throughout the duration of this project, the PI?s group provided a myriad of research opportunities for under-representative students and participated various outreach activities for the general public.


Last Modified: 04/23/2023
Modified by: Yujie Sun

Image
  • Electrocatalytic synthesis of heterocycles from biomass-derived furfuryl alcohols coupled with H2 evolution (Nature Communications, 2021, 12, 1868).
    Yujie Sun
    Copyrighted
    Yujie Sun
    A hybrid nickel electrocatalyst for biomass valorization
